content:
Ok, lets look at this.

1. the 4Gb limits on folder size were removed many years ago. So all that information is not irrelevant. Just an FYI, the issue was to do with how variables were defined in the C++ language and had nothing really to do with 32 or 64 bit versions. Although the issue did limit Linux and Mac to 2Gb at the time.

The can not write mailbox problem as you define it is mostly the result of anti virus products locking files in the profile folder while they scan them in their typical pedestrian manner. It is for this reason this forum is full of recommendations to exclude an on access scanning from the Thunderbird profile folder.

However the real issue is file contention, something Thunderbird simply can not handle, having grown up in a world where your files were available immediately and exclusively. So while I tend to reach for the antivirus card as the problem usually surfaces post update, anything that causes file contention can cause issues. So streaming backups, the profile being stored on a "cloud synced" location (something we are seeing more of), the profile not being stored locally on the system hard disk (while local network drives are supposed to work, they can be problematical and other things like NAS, and USB drives can also have built in contention issues.

Again just an FYI. I have an inbox on local folders of 7.4Gb containing almost 175,000 emails. I also have a GMail account connected as IMAP which has a 6.5Gb inbox with some 225,000 messages in it. While I do see "not responding" issues for which I have no solution (or even real cause) your issues will most likely be something external to Thunderbird, but that could include spam/Scam tools injected into Thunderbird by antivirus products that have not received the message their tools are not welcome in the running program.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: The columns live in a fixed width universe. You only get so much space for your chosen headings. This means is you want half the space for a message subject, the remaining half is for the rest of the items selected. Generally the date is the one affected most because all the space is used by the time you get that far to the right with your changes.

content: My suggestion is this: - import the current profile into new setup - exit Thunderbird - in Windows FIle Explorer, locate the desired message folders on old profile (normally two entries per folder) and copy them to the Mail\Local Folders folder. DO NOT attempt to merge old folders onto current folders as the old will overwrite the other. - restart Thunderbird and the messages should be there.

content:
Located bug report: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1765391

Suggest you disable the auto compact.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to 'Network & Disk Space' section
  • uncheck: 'Compact all folders when it will save.....'

Maybe not enough room to compact all folders at once, but have you tried to compact individual folders one at a time starting with 'Drafts' and then 'Junk/Spam' for each account and then try the 'Inbox' for each account starting with the smallest in size. eg: Right click on Drafts and select Compact.

Info in crash report says you are using version 102.15.1 Have you considered trying to upgrade to the current release 115.3.3? Create a backup of thunderbird first. Mac OS X Profile folders are located here:

  • ~/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/<Profile name>/

The tilde character (~) refers to the current user's Home folder, so ~/Library is the /Macintosh HD/Users/<username>/Library folder.

Suggest uninstall 102.15.1 and get a fresh download from here: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

content:
I see three bugs associated with the crash. All open.

1799247 REOPENED --- Crash in [@ nsMenuBarX::Paint] when opening Window menu with multiple monitors 1765391 NEW --- Crash in [@ nsMenuBarX::Paint] 1699936 REOPENED --- Crash in [@ nsMenuBarX::Paint] with NSInvalidArgumentException: *** -__NSArrayM insertObject:atIndex:]: object cannot be nil

I think the most relevant is 1799247 which talks about there being multiple monitors, Japanese language versions and the OWL addon in various other reports of this crash.

There is also discussion on activity in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1642138 which made it into Firefox on the 108 cycle, so should be in Thunderbird 115, but possibly not in 102 as I see nothing about a fix in the ESR branch on which current Thunderbird builds are based. That is the long way about saying V115 and 102 may offer different results on this.

I suggest you try;

  • Troubleshoot mode first (hold shift when starting Thunderbird.) This may give rise to video issues which can be addressed by disabling hardware acceleration in settings.
  • Reducing to a single monitor as you appear to be using an en_US version without any addons installed.

content: Not sure how I could make it more clear. My unified inbox has 4 different inboxes from different email addresses merged into one. When I reply to an email, the reply must be sent from one of those 4 different addresses, but for some reason, thunderbird does not always use the address that the received email was sent to as the default FROM address for the reply like most other email clients do. When you have a linked inbox in outlook or apple mail, this behavior is the default - those clients always use the TO address of the email you received as the FROM address of the email you are replying with. The TO and FROM addresses are never the same on any one email - not sure how you came to that conclusion from what I wrote.

content: Okay, now I understand. Yes, if you have four unique accounts, and the unified view makes them all appear virtually as one, when you reply, the FROM address should be the one that received the message. Are these each individual accounts, are are they aliases?

content: I think I may have found the solution (none of my accounts are aliases, they are all unique addresses). For each account, go under account settings and click the header with the address for the account which contains the account settings menu for that account. Then copy and paste the address of that account into the box beside "Reply from this identity when delivery headers match:" and check the box to the left. Doing this for all the accounts and closing and re opening thunderbird seems to have established the reply behavior I'm looking for.

content:
Generally attachments that essentially disappear between the providers web mail and Thunderbird are caused by antivirus programs. Either corrupting the email in transit with their "scanning" or more frequently in the building of the file in memory and in the system temp folder when you choose to open or save it.

The issue comes about because a "file" is not sent via email. When it is attached to an email the original file is disassembled and the contents is encoded in a text format called MIME. Then the email is send as a long sequence of plain text, indecipherable for most folks, but still plain text. When you receive the email and you ask to view or save the "file" which is listed in the attachment pane. The very first thing is this mime encoding has to be reversed to turn the pseudo "file" back into a file. This process occurs largely in memory, and on windows systems in the system temp folder where the resulting file is written. On mac systems the resulting file is written where ever the settings say. The issue is that the antivirus programs are so slow that at times the file is written and simply not available for the next step so the content is essentially corrupted.

Try in the first instance without an antivirus product.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
On D Drive: Create a folder called 'TBIRD'

Exit Thunderbird

  • In bottom Windows search type: %Appdata%
  • Select '%Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • Select 'Thunderbird'
  • Copy the 'Profiles' folder
  • Paste it into 'TBIRD' folder on D Drive. so you now have D://TBIRD/Profiles

Start thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' near the bottom - Profiles' - click on 'about:profiles'

It opens in a new tab

  • Click on 'Create a new Profile'
  • click on 'Next'
  • Enter a new user name eg: Default User
  • Click on 'Choose Folder'
  • navigate to the D Drive, locate and select the correct 'profile name' folder which is usually something like this 'abc1234d.default'
  • eg: D://TBIRD/Profiles/abc1234d.default
  • Click on 'Select Folder'
  • Click on 'Finish'

You should see a new Profile called 'Default User' appear in the list. It will say the 'Root directory: info will point to profile name in D drive.' Below it will be some buttons.

  • Click on 'Set as default profile'
  • Click on 'Launch Profile'

It will open Thunderbird on that new location in a new window.

  • Close/Exit the original Thunderbird window.

The above has auto edited the 'profiles.ini' file located in the 'Thunderbird' folder here:

  • C://Users/User name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Thunderbird is still using some files in that C Drive directory, but it should now be directed to the D Drive when it comes to the actual storage of mail.

Just check the following is ok.

  • Access Account Settings
  • Select 'Server Settings' for account in left pane
  • Look bottom right for 'Local directory'
  • Is it pointing to the correct location on 'D Drive' ?

eg: D://TBIRD/Profiles/profile name/Mail/mailaccountname If yes, no worries all is ok.

If no:

  • click on 'Browse'
  • A new window opens currently showing you the contents of that account name folder.
  • navigate to the D Drive, locate the same account name.
  • for a pop account eg: D://TBIRD/Profiles/profile name/Mail/mailaccountname
  • Select that mailaccount name folder and then click on 'Select Folder'
  • Do the same for each account.
  • Then do 'Local Folders'
  • Select 'Local Folders' in left pane
  • It will show 'local directory' - click on browse
  • navigate to the D Drive, locate 'Local Folders'
  • eg: D://TBIRD/Profiles/profile name/Mail/Local Folders
  • Select 'Local Folders' folder and click on 'Select Folder'

When all is working ok, do you want to recover some space on C: Drive? If yes, Exit Thunderbird, Access C Drive I would advise you keep all the main structure intact as there are some files still being used so Thunderbird knows where to look to locate stuff on D Drive, but remove all the folders that are containing a load of emails as they are using the most space.

  • C://Users/User name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/profile name folder

delete this file: global-mesasges-db.sqlite It's not actual emails - it's data used for global search you can safely delete

Then click on 'Mail' folder delete all the mail account name folders. delete 'smart mailboxes' folder if it exists.

Select the 'Local Folders' folder and delete all contents.

Back in 'profile name' folder - select 'ImapMail' folder delete all the imap mail account name folders.

content:
In Thunderbird - remote content is disabled by default, so even if any email with remote content was opened then nothing would happen. That's assuming you have not decided to enable it.

The Junk/Spam folder is a special case and regardless of your remote content settings Thunderbird does not permit any enabling of remote content. You have to set as not junk and move back to Inbox in order to manually select to see the remote content in that email.

Thunderbird takes security seriously, so you can rest assured it's not as bad as you first imagined.

The only place a register of 'read' may occur is on your server and that is also assuming you are using an imap account.

However, please check your settings as you may something set up to auto mark as read.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to 'Junk' section
  • uncheck 'Mark messages determined to be junk as read'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
it's not that it's as bad as i imagined, it's that it shouldn't happen at all. it's such a small thing and when the other emails are moved to other folders they are not marked as read, so it should be the default. i do run an i t security company so i think of security just a little more than most folks but this is an easy fix and one that while it may not have any uses to bad guys now that does not mean it doesn't have one sitting there waiting on someone to find it right now. don't get me wrong, i don't think that this in any way can be used for anything bad, at least right now, but if the notification gets past the local server then it gets back to the sender and it is worth it to me to keep that information away from them.

i appreciate the answer, but how would one ask a dev to make moving spam work like moving anything else?

edit: and i checked that part, it was unchecked already. thanx for replying! have a great weekend.
creator: tim265

content:
re : i appreciate the answer, but how would one ask a dev to make moving spam work like moving anything else?

First we would need to find out how they are getting marked as read because you say you are using the default do not mark as read.

Thunderbird default is to not mark as read. The following should auto be unchecked.

  • uncheck 'Mark messages determined to be junk as read'

You say " and i checked that part, it was unchecked already. " This setting deals with any emails that you mark as junk or Thunderbird marks as junk via junk Controls..

Just checking... but those emails that are in Spam/Junk: Do they have a red/yellow junk flame icon or is it grey ?

If it red/yellow then Thunderbird marked it as Junk. If it is grey then the server marked it as spam and put it into the server spam folder. If grey then please logon to webmail account and find out if you have a setting which is auto marking spam as read.

re:stop letting thunderbird open the email when it moves to the spam folder. Do you find the spam email when moved to Spam/Junk is auto opened and displaying in the Message Pane ?

Do you have any Message Filters which mark certain emails as Junk and put into Spam/Junk Folder? If yes, Do you notice if it is only those emails that seem to get marked as read?

Or...is it you manually marking an unopened email in list as Junk via right click Mark as Junk and it is those emails which get marked as read ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
-Just checking... but those emails that are in Spam/Junk: Do they have a red/yellow junk flame icon or is it grey ?- most of them don't have anything there, no flames at all, but the ones that have them are all red. -Do you find the spam email when moved to Spam/Junk is auto opened and displaying in the Message Pane ?- message pane disabled so no way to tell, but i suspect it would not. -Do you have any Message Filters which mark certain emails as Junk and put into Spam/Junk Folder? If yes, Do you notice if it is only those emails that seem to get marked as read?- yes i have the filters set and no they do not become opened after they are moved. this is how i can tell the default is not to open them and that it should not be a big deal to make all of them unopened when they are moved. -Or...is it you manually marking an unopened email in list as Junk via right click Mark as Junk and it is those emails which get marked as read ?- when i just tried it, it marked the email as junk after it opened it first, then left it in the folder it was in, a local folder i had a rule to move it to. then since i had no unopened email in the inbox, i marked one as unread, then as junk. it opened the email immediately then moved it to the spam folder and left it opened. when i marked it as not junk, it went back to the inbox and was marked unread.

this is not a good behavior and it needs to be fixed. if it can intercept spam that i have marked as junk manually and not open it when moving it, then it can also not open the damned thing when i mark it as junk.
creator: tim265

content:
Your question say this: thunderbird opens spam emails when moving to spam folder

The only way you would know if an email had been opened would be to enable the Message Pane and then select the 'Junk/Spam folder. Do NOT select anything in the list of emails in that folder. Is there spam emails auto displaying in the Message Pane and you have never selected them at any point?

re :message pane disabled so no way to tell,

Then the emails are not being opened. I expect that if Message Pane was enabled you would not see anything it unless you selected something in the Junk spam folder.

So i think you are asking the wrong question. This has nothing to do with opened emails.

I think you are talking about emails in the junk folder which are being 'marked as read' - aka they are not bold. Is that correct?



re :when i just tried it, it marked the email as junk after it opened it first, then left it in the folder it was in,

How can it be opened if you do not have the 'Message Pane' enabled ?

I do not think you are using the correct terminology. Opening an email means you single clicked on the email in the list and it opened in the 'Message Pane' so you can see the content of that opened email OR you double clicked on email in list to open in a new tab so you can see the contents.

Somehow, I think you are talking about emails that are getting 'marked as read' - email in list bold font becomes not bold and the green button which indictates it is unread gets switched off.

Just been testing this on a gmail imap account. Have an email in Inbox which I've marked as unread. Font is bold and it has a green button. I select an email above just to make sure target email is not selected so it is not open. Right click on target email and select 'Mark as Junk'

AS per my account settings and preferences - Email gets moved to 'Spam' and when I look in spam it is now marked as read.

I'm going to put this action as a bug. It should never be marked as read. Bug reported:

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1860444
creator: Toad-Hall

content: First, do a backup of the profile. I presume that is at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird You should be able to upgrade over what you have, although the profile may be somewhat incompatible, depending on how old it is. The generally suggested approach is to upgrade to the first of each release to get up to date, such as in this link: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/releases/ e.g., 78.0.1, 91.0.1, 102.0.1. Your accounts, messages, and addressbook should remain intact. If you do follow the staged upgrade, I further suggest doing a backup as identified above after each upgrade to minimize any problems.

content:
The fonts for the Menu Bar and context menus can be adjusted with css: 

/* Menu Bar font */ menubar > menu { font-size: 14px !important; font-weight: bold !important; font-family: Times, serif !important; }  /* Submenus and context menus font */ menupopup,popup {     font-size: 12pt !important;     font-weight: bold !important;     font-family: Times, serif !important; }


Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the parameters as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator
creator: sfhowes

content:
How to increase the height or width of the Message Pane:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1427439#answer-1611585

The Header Pane height can be reduced to a single line with the Compact Headers add-on. Also, consider View/Layout/Vertical View for a larger Message Pane. The Header Pane can be hidden with css, or just the buttons, with an add-on.

content:
If you have Norton 360 then you need to make sure the Firewall has Thunderbird as an allowed program otherwise it will block all access. No point in disabling Norton because then your default firewall will take over and it could also be blocking access.

I use Norton 360 and never had any issue, but you must set up Thunderbird as an allowed program. If it was already set up, then exit Thunderbird. Access Firewall, block Thunderbird and ok it. Then go back into Firwall and set Thunderbird as allowed. Why do this ? Because I have discovered in the past that Norton seems to think an update in Thunderbird was a new different program and it was confused. See image below as a guide.

On another occasion, I discovered that Norton had auto switched on it's VPN which plays havoc because then you discover the servers do not like it, so they may be refusing access to server. So check for the VPN option in Norton and switch it off.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Toad-Hall Thanks for the info about Norton's. My email is working now and Thunderbird is an allowed program. However if I run into problems in the future, I will follow your suggestions. Thanks.

content:
and is that address configured as an identity with it's own SMTP server entry? Not using a shared gmail server or something. You appear to be using google, and like Microsoft I understand they modify outgoing mail to use the information they have stored on their web server for your account regarding name email address etc.

I would assume you would use the SMTP server of the original account to send mail from that account.

creator: fosterbrown

content:
For what it is worth (not much) I did test your SSL security on the server as that was a real possibility (servers often have corporate SSL certificates that mismatch what they are hosting as) and that was all on the up and up, but the fact they do not support TLS V1.3 is something that should be at least raised with them as it is inherently more secure than older versions. There is also potential for connection initiated encryption downgrades that leave the servers "more" prone to denial of service attacks.

If you understand the stuff enough, knowing what blocklist they used to block your IP may help you in the future. A certain US based ISP keeps placing their own IP addresses into an SMTP blocklist because they are dynamically allocated and apparently should not send mail (even to their own SMTP server) They use a blocklist from spamhaus.

In a world of Microsoft Exchange servers which do not use any of the open source protocols by default, technicians for SMTP servers are, I think in short supply, so silly things keep getting done.
creator: MattAuSupport
